metadata.title: Get Extra Credit at Your DS Job by Taking a Work Side Project | by Marina Gandlin | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Get Extra Credit at Your DS Job by Taking a Work Side Project
metadata.description: So it’s been a while since you’ve started work, things are looking good and your days are probably filled with perfecting some core model. But after a while you might be interested in freshening your…

all_paragraphs: So it’s been a while since you’ve started work, things are looking good and your days are probably filled with perfecting some core model. But after a while you might be interested in freshening your task list: Have you just finished something big and looking for a small task to break routine? Suffer from “writer’s block” and not sure what to do next? Or maybe you just want to get noticed towards that raise you’re planning to ask for? There are many ways to deal with these situations, but once in a while, if you’re looking to add something new to your schedule — I suggest you take a work side project!

Even if your company does have a data science team, it’s a fair guess there’s still plenty of places and plenty of data that haven’t reached their full potential. I’m talking about tasks from outside the data science team that might help other workers or the company: Are you familiar with some data nobody is touching yet and you could help distill some insights or predictions from? Maybe the sales department wants a model for seasonality? Or for which costumers might churn next? Maybe the fraud department could get help automating catching the bad guys? If you have a hard time thinking of examples, just ask your boss or colleagues if they could think of something. If this fails — go to the closest analysts team.

Analysts are great people. They are naturally inquisitive, super thorough, and usually hold priceless domain knowledge which they perfected over months and years. They are probably great with SQL, databases and dashboards. The best are even wicked with some python scripting, using pandas or sklearn. But, even if they are top notch they usually fall short with stuff most data scientist can do: use machine learning, which is where you come in!

If you still can’t think of who and how you can help by now, go and directly talk to the analysts team: Ask about their tasks, what do they do that takes up much of their time, what features they look at when they’re doing analysis. If they already use some kind of structured data, maybe wisely mashing it with other data might work? Ask nicely, and only a few people would refuse help. If you were able to find a clue for a possible task — now it’s money time. Try to walk away with a dummy CSV you could play around with. It doesn’t have to be long or complicated or even have all possible columns, just something for you to start with.

Do not (DO NOT!) patronize, look down or think you could eliminate someone’s job by mere automatization and a fancy jupyter notebook. Whatever code you might be writing will probably be used by the people you interviewed. They’ll be the ones running it and the ones to figure out if what you’re doing is any good. Their cooperation is crucial for the success of this project. Try to see what’s their pain point. Describe possible outcomes of your joint project and see if this gets them excited.

Make sure you don’t choose data that needs much fussing and cleaning. Remember, you actually already have a full time job, and we’re just reaching out to some low hanging fruit. Take the data, understand the type of problem you’re trying to solve (regression? classification?), then just run a simple model. See if you manage to actually predict something. Look at feature importance and see if something useful pops out.

I got tapped to help my company’s fraud team to model fraud. Until now, The analysts were doing SQL queries on some databases. They had previous knowledge about 2–3 features that work well, and looked at the top scoring items in those features with SQL queries. These items were marked as suspicious and the analysts would go over them manually to check if their other qualities align to be suspicious as well. Even though this worked, it took a long time and it was obvious to me together we could do better: Why look at only 2–3 features when we have tens of others?

I got a sample CSV that contained 1600 lines of historical fraud and non fraud exchanges, with 8 features. I used python’s Catboost tree boosting package to model this classification problem. The model is now run by the analysts who periodically add more features they think of to improve the model. Estimates are that this made the process of eliminating fraud at least x5 faster.

I highly recommend the Catboost gradient boosting package for these tasks. It is so powerful and simple to use, that it probably takes only 1–2 hours to set up the first working model, even if you haven’t heard about this package before. It’s very fast even if you run on your computer; handles tabular data very well and uses categorical features without the need for preprocessing (no 1-hot encoding! just marking which column is categorical). It works excellent even with no hyperparameter tuning. Of course, other things you like and familiar with are good too, as long as you keep in mind that someday, people who aren’t you might want to run it, so keep it simple.

That’s basically it. Worst case scenario is this experiment wasted 3–4 hours with no effect. Best case scenario, you made a new friend, maybe learned something new and did something that’s going to be useful (dare I say even very useful) for a long while. Try it!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Data science team lead at Taboola. Used to design satellites, but thinks recommendation systems are way cooler.
